STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 7, 2020
Jennifer Savage
Benzie/Manistee DHHS
1672 US-31 South
Manistee, MI 49660
RE: License #: CP510201273
Benzie/Manistee DHHS
1672 US-31 South
Manistee, MI 49660
Dear Ms. Savage:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on September
24, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager, at 616-552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 383-5531
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Services

Lansing, MI 48902

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(1) An agency shall have a written foster parent/agency
agreement signed by the foster parent and the agency before
initially certifying a foster home for licensure.
Three foster home files were reviewed. One of 3 files did not contain documentation
that the parent/agency agreement was provided to the foster parent before initially
certifying the foster home for licensure.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. Two of 3 files contained a service plan
that was late. One file contained a USP that was due on June 18, 2020 and was
completed on June 19, 2020, the plan was 1 day late. A second file contained a USP
that was due on August 16, 2020 and was completed on August 25, 2020. The plan
was 9 days late. This is a repeat violation. The original violation was established
during the renewal inspection completed on September 5, 2019 and an acceptable
corrective action plan was received on September 30, 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports
At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
4

“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. Four of 6 files contained passports that
were late or did not contain signatures. In 1 file there was a 5 month gap between
updated passports. The gap time period was from November 20, 2019 to April 29,
2020. In a second file there also was a 5 month gap from July 16, 2019 to December
23, 2019. A third file did not document signatures for a July 22, 2020 passport. This
is a repeat violation. The original violation was established during the renewal
inspection completed on September 5, 2019 and an acceptable corrective
action plan was received on September 30, 2019
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Timely Entry of Face to Face Contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the contact.
This includes attempted and missed face-to-face contacts.
Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. Four of 6 files had 2 or more face to
face contacts that were not entered in the required time frame. This is a repeat
violation. The original violation was established during the renewal inspection
completed on September 5, 2019 and an acceptable corrective action plan was
received on September 30, 2019.
FOM 722-06H Quality Visits/Caseworker Contacts
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts per
month with each child in the first two months following an initial
placement or a placement.
At least one contact each month must take place in the child’s
placement setting.
5

Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. One of 6 files documented that a video
face to face conference with the foster home occurred however there was no
narrative describing the visit. This is a repeat violation. The original violation was
established during the renewal inspection completed on September 5, 2019
and an acceptable corrective action plan was received on September 30, 2019.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. One of 6 files did not contain
documentation that an FTM occurred within 30 days for the August 16, 2020 service
plan. This is a repeat violation. The original violation was established during
the renewal inspection completed on September 5, 2019 and an acceptable
corrective action plan was received on September 30, 2019.
FOM 722-08C Parent/Agency Treatment Plans
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
6

Six files and 18 service plans were reviewed. Two files each contained a PATP that
was not signed by the caregiver. In one file a PATP dated June 16, 2020 did not
documents signatures. In a second file a PATP dated May 18, 2020 did not
document signatures.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Not required.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on September 30, 2019
in response to those violations established during the renewal audit completed on
September 5, 2019.
There were no complaints against the agency during the licensing period therefore
no special investigations were conducted.
The DCWL analyst did not report any safety concerns in the home visited.
7

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 1, 2020
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 7, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
8
